message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) and can be treated with oral contraceptives and NSAIDs. Anxiolytic therapy or nonserotonergic antidepressants may be helpful in some cases, but are not the first-line treatment for PMDD. SSRIs can also be effective, but in this case, the patient is using contraception and may not desire additional hormonal treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) symptoms, which is characterized by mood swings, irritability, breast tenderness, bloating, fatigue, binge-eating, and difficulty concentrating during the premenstrual phase. Oral contraceptives and NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for PMDD. Anxiolytic therapy and non-serotonergic antidepressants may be used in refractory cases. While SSRIs are also approved for PMDD, the patient has no history of depression and may prefer non-pharmacological treatments.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), which can be treated with oral contraceptives and NSAIDs. Anxiolytic therapy and nonserotonergic antidepressants are not the first-line treatments for PMDD, and although SSRIs can be effective, they are not the most appropriate first step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), and among the options, oral contraceptives and NSAIDs have been shown to be effective in treating PMDD. Anxiolytic therapy and SSRIs may be helpful for general anxiety and depression, but they are not specific for PMDD. Nonserotonergic antidepressants have not been shown to be effective in treating PMDD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). Oral contraceptives and NSAIDs are the first-line treatments for PMDD. Anxiolytic therapy and nonserotonergic antidepressants are not first-line treatments for PMDD, and SSRIs are only considered if the first-line treatment is ineffective or not tolerated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), which is characterized by severe mood and physical symptoms during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. Combination oral contraceptives can help regulate menstrual cycles and reduce PMDD symptoms. NSAIDs can also help manage physical symptoms. It is important to address birth control in a patient with PMDD because mood symptoms may be exacerbated by hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle. Anxiolytic therapy and nonserotonergic antidepressants may not specifically target PMDD symptoms while SSRIs may be effective but are not the first line of treatment for PMDD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest premenstrual syndrome (PMS). The most appropriate next step is treatment with oral contraceptives and NSAIDs to alleviate the patient's symptoms. Anxiolytic therapy and nonserotonergic antidepressants are not effective for PMS, while SSRIs can be considered but are not the first-line treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the patient's symptoms suggests premenstrual syndrome (PMS). Oral contraceptive and NSAIDs may be used for the treatment of PMS. Anxiolytic therapy or nonserotonergic antidepressants may not be helpful for the specific symptom profile, and SSRIs may have limited efficacy in PMS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient reports symptoms of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) which includes changes in mood and physical symptoms prior to menstrual period, and symptoms resolve with the onset of menses. Oral contraceptives and NSAIDs are recommended for the treatment of PMDD, as they can help regulate the menstrual cycle and reduce symptoms. Anxiolytic therapy and nonserotonergic antidepressants may also be options, but are not the first-line treatment for PMDD. SSRI can be an option but oral contraceptives and NSAIDs are more effective.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and regular menstrual cycles suggest premenstrual syndrome (PMS). Oral contraceptives and NSAIDs are first-line treatments for PMS. Anxiolytic therapy or nonserotonergic antidepressants may be considered if symptoms persist despite treatment with first-line options or if there is a comorbid anxiety or mood disorder. SSRIs may be helpful for the treatment of PMS, but they are not typically considered first-line options unless symptoms are severe or have not responded to other treatments.
